channel.title: A world with no religion
channel.description: What do you think the world will be like? Maybe people will stop relying on god as an answer and maybe have a more advancement in science like more people would start being scientists then saying god did everything. What do you think the world will be like? There would be less discrimination and stuff against Jews and other religions. And world war II would have never happened. What do you think?

item.title: A world with no religion
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

i’ve always wished that more states followed the old roman policy in dealing with christians

Read full topic

item.title: A world with no religion
item.dc:creator: @Fire_capez Fire capez
item.description:
@Fire_capez wrote:

It would be much worse then it is now; the notion of religion has for centuries put people in their place, you don’t defy God and pursue your own agenda for if you do you spend eternity in hell (if you follow Christian doctrines). Now if you pursue your own agenda (say you kill someone) you get put in jail for 25 years (but you get let out sooner most of the time) and get to live your life paid at the expense of the tax payer without worry of work, crime is much worse today because most people don’t believe in the concept of a God and thus think they can get away with anything they want. Now I understand religion has caused many wars (the crusades, the conflict in Palestine) but it’s human nature; if it wasn’t religion it would be some other excuse to go to war.

Read full topic

item.title: A world with no religion
item.dc:creator: @Cole1497 Cole1497
item.description:
@Cole1497 wrote:

[quote=“m1lkman, post:123, topic:458042”][quote author=Cole1497 link=topic=560966.msg4268238#msg4268238 date=1364302601]
And which part is funny? That the catholic church was actively executing people who didn’t follow their religion? That’s pretty humorous.
[/quote]
You are sick to think that the Catholic church executing people is funny.[/quote]
You said the reason your signature was what it was is because you thought it was funny, and you’ve since redacted that message, and I was asking what part of it was considered funny. You’d have to be an inept jackass to think that I was being serious.

Read full topic

item.title: A world with no religion
item.dc:creator: @m1lkman m1lkman
item.description:
@m1lkman wrote:

Cole1497:

And which part is funny? That the catholic church was actively executing people who didn’t follow their religion? That’s pretty humorous.

You are sick to think that the Catholic church executing people is funny.

p.s., I came to my conclusion based on your signature which cuts off after saying that the church executed people

I understand. I would’ve done the whole thing but you can only have 250 characters in your signature.

but, why you ask am I talking about heliocentrism and not a round earth? because wodskill4eva mentioned that people were executed by the churches for holding both ideas, while not strictly true (at least from 1000-1700 for round earth), the churches did execute people for holding the idea of heliocentrisim as it was heresy and in contradiction of the churches scripture, the whole point of wodskill4eva's post was that the churches executed people who held different ideas, even if those ideas were discussed in a scientific context, simply because it was considered heresy, and while good on you m1lkman (that is not intended to sound sarcastic) for correcting him for stating people were executed for saying the earth was round, I feel you missed the point of the post

He mixed the heliocentric theory with the flat earth theory which I thought, combined with his poor sentence structure, word choice, and snarky tone, was pretty funny.

I now understand that I misinterpreted his post. Wodskill4eva, I apologize for calling you stupid.

Read full topic

item.title: A world with no religion
item.dc:creator: @TabbyKiller TabbyKiller
item.description:
@TabbyKiller wrote:

If there is such thing as magic, it wouldn’t be done through casting spells and magic words, it would have something to do with natural energy and enhancing and controlling that energy. I don’t think as much as believing, but I’m open minded and I will not argue otherwise until I’ve tried and/or seen it.

It sure would be an interesting topic to do research on when bored but I really don’t think there’s a point to arguing about something that cannot be proven right or wrong.

Read full topic

item.title: A world with no religion
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

[quote=“m1lkman, post:116, topic:458042”][quote author=Niall link=topic=560966.msg4267661#msg4267661 date=1364239034]

First of, if there was no religion, no Christianity, means we woulda been very advanced in science, since from 1000 to mid 1700 people were executed by churches because they said world is round, we circle around the sun, not the otherway around n shit, i’d love to see that work

You are so stupid.

since you have failed to explain your argument I will assume you take issue with the fact that wodskill4eva claims people were executed by the churches, in which case, he is correct, people WERE executed by christian (more specifically, catholic) churches, have you ever heard of the spanish inquisition? you know, where churches executed and tortured people for heresy?
[/quote]

My first issue with his post was that it was barely readable. I assumed since this was intellectual discussion and debates, posts were held to a higher standard. I guess they aren’t.[/quote]

wodskill4eva may have made a silly post but this is the debates board, if someone makes a post that you disagree with then you are quite welcome to offer a rebuttal to an argument, if you want to hold people to a higher standard you must hold yourself to the same standard, you made a borderline troll post and were called out on it, now you’re trying to shift the blame to wodskill4eva?

p.s., I came to my conclusion based on your signature which cuts off after saying that the church executed people

m1lkman:

[quote]people were executed by churches because they said world is round, we circle around the sun, not the otherway around n shit,

The Catholic Church did not argue that the world was flat. In fact, from what I have read about the subject, many Christian scholars supported the notion that the world was round. These Christian scholars range from Saint Augustine (354–430) to Thomas Aquinas (1225–1274), an Italian Dominican priest, and an immensely influential philosopher and theologian.

Thomas Aquinas:

“The physicist proves the earth to be round by one means, the astronomer by another: for the latter proves this by means of mathematics, e.g. by the shapes of eclipses, or something of the sort; while the former proves it by means of physics, e.g. by the movement of heavy bodies towards the center, and so forth.”

In 1492, when Columbus sailed the ocean blue, they found “practical proofs” that the Earth was round.[/quote]

while the catholic church may or may not have argued that the earth was flat, the catholic church argued that the earth was the centre of the universe, and this is well documented most famously by the condemnation of galileo in 1633, I quote the roman catholic church in 1633:

“The doctrine that the earth is neither the center of the universe nor immovable, but moves even with a daily rotation, is absurd, and both psychologically and theologically false, and at the least an error of faith.”

as to the roundness of the earth, well yeah, you’re generally right, christian scholars generally held the idea that the earth was round to be correct, as did all worthy scholars, the idea of a round earth has been traced back as far as 6th century bc, and the greeks estimated the earths circumference in 240 bc (which depending on the length of the measurement they used, exact length is unknown, the estimate in 240 bc was between 2% and 20% accurate of the actual circumference of the earth)

sailors especially have always known that the earth is round, if the earth was flat then you would be able to see all the ships on the ocean as long as your eyes could resolve them, I believe the original idea that sparked the idea of a round earth was that when sailing, the masts of ships would appear before the bottom of the ship

but, why you ask am I talking about heliocentrism and not a round earth? because wodskill4eva mentioned that people were executed by the churches for holding both ideas, while not strictly true (at least from 1000-1700 for round earth), the churches did execute people for holding the idea of heliocentrisim as it was heresy and in contradiction of the churches scripture, the whole point of wodskill4eva’s post was that the churches executed people who held different ideas, even if those ideas were discussed in a scientific context, simply because it was considered heresy, and while good on you m1lkman (that is not intended to sound sarcastic) for correcting him for stating people were executed for saying the earth was round, I feel you missed the point of the post

m1lkman:

I’m sure I would be flamed if I posted a barely legible reply that made me seem like a snarky idiot who didn’t know what the hell I was talking about. But hey, that’s moparscape for you!

and this really is why I replied, without sounding mean you are a complete hypocrite for stating that, your defence of flaming someone for a post is that you yourself would be flamed for making the same post? you could have replied to wodskill4eva without the snarky bullshit but you chose not to, at least, until being called out on it, and this really goes back to my first sentence in this post, if you’re going to hold people to a high standard then you have to hold yourself to the same standard if you want any credibility

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Cole1497 Cole1497
item.description:
@Cole1497 wrote:

Clawz fury:

its only real if you believe its real

It’s real if there’s factual evidence supporting it

Clawz fury:

This is why non believers have never been able to use Ouija boards and such

I’m pretty sure believers find that it works from placebo, or people are just lying, but there’s no evidence to support that they grant contact with the deceased, demons, spirits, whatever you want to call them

Cole1497:

practicing witchcraft does not make magic real

its only real if you believe its real. This is why non believers have never been able to use Ouija boards and such. What makes it work is the energy you put into it

personally I believe magic is real

item.title: A world with no religion
item.dc:creator: @m1lkman m1lkman
item.description:
@m1lkman wrote:

[quote=“Niall, post:115, topic:458042”][quote author=m1lkman link=topic=560966.msg4267082#msg4267082 date=1364163550]

First of, if there was no religion, no Christianity, means we woulda been very advanced in science, since from 1000 to mid 1700 people were executed by churches because they said world is round, we circle around the sun, not the otherway around n shit, i’d love to see that work

You are so stupid.
[/quote]

since you have failed to explain your argument I will assume you take issue with the fact that wodskill4eva claims people were executed by the churches, in which case, he is correct, people WERE executed by christian (more specifically, catholic) churches, have you ever heard of the spanish inquisition? you know, where churches executed and tortured people for heresy?[/quote]

My first issue with his post was that it was barely readable. I assumed since this was intellectual discussion and debates, posts were held to a higher standard. I guess they aren’t.

[hr]

people were executed by churches because they said world is round, we circle around the sun, not the otherway around n shit,

The Catholic Church did not argue that the world was flat. In fact, from what I have read about the subject, many Christian scholars supported the notion that the world was round. These Christian scholars range from Saint Augustine (354–430) to Thomas Aquinas (1225–1274), an Italian Dominican priest, and an immensely influential philosopher and theologian.

"The physicist proves the earth to be round by one means, the astronomer by another: for the latter proves this by means of mathematics, e.g. by the shapes of eclipses, or something of the sort; while the former proves it by means of physics, e.g. by the movement of heavy bodies towards the center, and so forth."

In 1492, when Columbus sailed the ocean blue, they found “practical proofs” that the Earth was round.

The Jesuits actually taught that the Earth was round in 17th Century China:

In the 17th century, the idea of a spherical Earth spread in China due to the influence of the Jesuits, who held high positions as astronomers at the imperial court. The Ge Chi Cao treatise of Xiong Ming-yu (1648) showed a printed picture of the Earth as a spherical globe, with the text stating that "the round earth certainly has no square corners".[122] The text also pointed out that sailing ships could return to their port of origin after circumnavigating the waters of the Earth.[122]
[hr]

I’m sure I would be flamed if I posted a barely legible reply that made me seem like a snarky idiot who didn’t know what the hell I was talking about. But hey, that’s moparscape for you!

Read full topic

[/quote]

You are so stupid.[/quote]

since you have failed to explain your argument I will assume you take issue with the fact that wodskill4eva claims people were executed by the churches, in which case, he is correct, people WERE executed by christian (more specifically, catholic) churches, have you ever heard of the spanish inquisition? you know, where churches executed and tortured people for heresy?

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Cole1497 Cole1497
item.description:
@Cole1497 wrote:

axlrose103:

I’m not sure if his years are correct, they might be or not. But he is correct on the fact that the catholic church was beheading people because of Plato’s theory that the world is round, and orbits the sun. So i’m not sure why you are calling him stupid. Perhaps he is historically incorrect on the time period. But he is correct about the be-headings. I thought this was a forum section for intelligent conversation. I guess you missed that part “stupid.”

M1lkman is a diehard Christian so if things go against his beliefs he’ll probably get a bit defensive, but calling someone stupid because he disagrees is a little bit out of hand.

item.title: A world with no religion
item.dc:creator: @axlrose103 axlrose103
item.description:
@axlrose103 wrote:

Well everyone seems to agree there would be less war, more scientific achievement such as stem cell research, better cosmological understanding, etc. I also believe the world would have less intolerance towards one another. Also pesky, blatant ignorance such as westboro baptist church would no long hinder us. I believe Gay people would have equal rights, abortion would be safe and legal in every state. (North Dakota just banned abortion because of religious politicians.) Evolution would also be taught in every school because it is not A belief it is A well documented fact.

Read full topic
